How it works is that whatever money that isn't spent within a particular budget ends up being upper management's bonus at the year-end. They have no real intention of keeping you around. Why you may ask? They can always hire a new face who have no idea what's going on behind the curtains 85% of market value, have them disappointed, see them leave, continue to pocket the bonus, rinse and repeat. The longer you stay here, you're missing out in real growth and meaningful opportunities. Stay away unless you're absolutely desperate for a job. They don't match anything in your first 2 years. Beware.

review_title: Prepare to be Undervalued at all Times
pros: The work is easy and engaging. The medical benefits are good, the pay is average for the region.
cons:
Do you have a disability? If you answered Yes, then don't even bother applying here!

I have a chronic condition that qualifies as a disability. I had a lot of sick days because of it, so I asked for ADA accommodations. HR said that they can't meet my requests and that they don't think it qualifies as a disability at all. When I pointed out to my boss that this is discriminatory and illegal, she backpedaled that she never had a problem with my sick days, and it was about my communication skills. Never missed any meetings or emails ever, even showed all of my sent emails to the director to prove that my communication was great. Nope, evidence and proof didn't matter, all that mattered was that I was sick too often.

To this company, sick people are only good as patients that can earn them money, there is no value to any employee who gets sick. "Forefront of Medicine" is a total lie.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Chicago, IL
pros:
*The pay is higher than any place I worked at. 
*There is usually enough supply for you to get the job done.
*I was lucky to get awesome managers at the two units that I have worked in.
*School accommodation is available in some units.
*$2000 annual tuition reimbursement for full-time, $1000 for part-time.
*Financial assistance for child care through Bright Horizons
cons:
*Some of the nurses can be passive aggressive, especially in days. Definitely get in contact with your union steward because there is under reported bullying. 
*No COVID hazard pay. 
*Overtime occurs after you work 40 hrs and there is no incentive if you pick up extra shifts even though the hospital is always short. The nurses get $400 incentive for picking up an extra day regardless if they are part-time.
*UofC pays agency CNAs more than us, and they are usually given sitter cases.
*If you work part-time, your health insurance is double. My PPO plan is $930 per month. I only have a $20 co-pay if I go to the University of Chicago network, but I pay %10 of my total bill if I go out of network.

job_title: Physical Therapist in South Holland, IL
pros:
-Coworkers are hardworking and knowledgable 
-Patient cancellation rate is comparable to other hospital systems in the area - floating around the industry average of 15%
cons:
-Employee turnover has become a huge problem at all UofC/Ingalls OP therapy clinics (especially South Holland and Calumet City locations) with >5 therapists leaving within the past year alone. 
-New senior management placed within the past year has made minimal effort to combat this or retain current employees. Additionally, upper management have little to no clinical experience and come from either business/law backgrounds with a business first approach. The end result is overworked therapists and decreased quality of care for patients. 
-Inconsistent scheduling results in a random hodgepodge of a caseload shared between multiple PTAs and part-time employees. 
-Evaluating therapists should anticipate a minimum of 10 new patient evaluations per week. 
-Benefits are subpar - even following the advertised Ingalls/UofC merger, Ingalls employees are not entitled to UofC benefits, which further raises questions as to why new position openings are being posted under UofC solely and not Ingalls Memorial. The 403b offered is non-competitive with other hospital systems in the area and requires over 2 years of service in order to vest a 50% match up to 6%. Their Aetna Ingalls Provider Group EPO insurance, while affordable, provides minimal coverages and I have struggled to get claims processed through them for things as simple as a yearly wellness screen within their network. 
-Continuing education money is almost non-existent following the merger.

pros:
The first, and most obvious, is the prestige associated with The University of Chicago. 

Their benefits are good in some ways: 3 weeks of vacation, 5 personal days, and 10 sick days per year right off the bat. Insurance options are good and reflect the philosophy "you get what you pay for". 

Very diverse work environment.
cons:
Benefit cons: 6 holidays require many employees to use personal days to observe the holidays of their choice (Christian, Jewish, American, etc). It would be nice if they offered "floating holidays" due to the wide diversity of employees and enough days that employees wouldn't have to use their personal days for holidays. 

If you are hourly, they will rarely if ever approve overtime. If you are salary, expect to have to work more than a 40 hour week. Simple put, human resources (aka employees) are not what UofC/UCM want to invest in. Even doctors and professors are often paid 10% less than the average. 

Many managers have limited "real world" experience and are rigid for unnecessary reason. They will not consider many things outside of the historic work weeks/schedules, usage of breaks, etc. Things like 4 days work weeks or even just employees managing their own time is not an option for most employees. 

Unions play a far too large role at UofC/UCM. They have a tight hold on the workforce and that in turn creates a very stressful and frustrating environment for many employees.

pros: I love working here, you get to see rare cases and conditions. it is a great place to learn. most of the people are great to work with. They are very knowledgeable and willing to teach.
cons: does not provide substantial financial support for educational advancement (i.e. getting a graduate degree) unless you are a nurse. does not support cross training/continuing education that will lead to career advancement, management is usually not accessible/open to suggestions

pros: University of Chicago Medical Center is located in Hyde Park. The staff is diverse and I found myself be pleased with the work environment and variety of research opportunities to become involved in.
cons: The medical center on S. Maryland Ave. is a bit old and outdated. I worked in the basement of the medical center which had a serious cockroach problem!!!!!! Also the bathrooms and staircases were always dusty, but then again I am a germaphobe!

review_title: It was the best hospital experience I've had, with the exception of being laid off.
job_title: Training Manager in North Chicago, IL
pros: It's prestige, it's opportunities for learning & collaborating, it's cutting edge research, & it's diversity.
cons: Well, if you work in support services, you're subject to being outsourced, as I was. They seem to go through a cycle of outsourcing & going in house every 5 years or so. New administrations don't learn from the mistakes of previous administrations.

review_title: Over all a great place to get some good experience

review_title: The organization was going through a transition.

pros: Simple and provided experience for clerical work. I did like the freedom of coming in whenever I had time to come in.

pros: Great hospital and company with worldwide brand recognition. Great benefits (medical, dental, etc) and good amount of vacation. Smart people leading the organization at the top. For those who work hard, upward mobility is endless.

pros: There were no perks on this unit.

If you complain to the nurse manager on the unit, she sides with them. All nurses hated working in that unit because they were called onto that unit to work, while the medical assistants and some of the unit nurses would just sit down and chat with each other. Lots of bullying in that department.
